title: Sheldon Allman
text:
Sheldon Allman (June 8, 1924 – January 22, 2002) was an American-Canadian actor, <a href="singer">singer</a>, and <a href="songwriter">songwriter</a>.
Early life and career.
Allman was born in Chicago, Illinois. He began his singing career with the Royal National Guard during his <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> service with the <a href="Royal%20Canadian%20Air%20Force">Royal Canadian Air Force</a>. He moved to <a href="Los%20Angeles">Los Angeles</a> in 1949, in order to attend the <a href="California%20Institute%20of%20the%20Arts">Los Angeles Conservatory of Music</a>. After it, he appeared in 12 films, including such notable films as "<a href="Nevada%20Smith">Nevada Smith</a>", "<a href="The%20Sons%20of%20Katie%20Elder">The Sons of Katie Elder</a>", "<a href="Hud%20%281963%20film%29">Hud</a>" and "<a href="In%20Cold%20Blood%20%28film%29">In Cold Blood</a>". His co-stars included, respectively, <a href="Steve%20McQueen">Steve McQueen</a>, <a href="John%20Wayne">John Wayne</a> and <a href="Paul%20Newman">Paul Newman</a>. He also made appearances in numerous TV series during the 1960s and 1970s.
On television, Allman provided the voice of Big H in "<a href="CB%20Bears">CB Bears</a>" on CBS and played Norm Miller in "<a href="90%20Bristol%20Court%23Harris%20Against%20the%20World">Harris Against the World</a>" on NBC. He provided music on the game show "<a href="Three%20for%20the%20Money">Three for the Money</a>" on NBC, and he was the singing voice for TV's "<a href="Mister%20Ed">Mister Ed</a>", for which he also wrote and recorded "The Pretty Little Filly with the Ponytail" and "The Empty Feedbag Blues". Mr. Allman wrote longer versions of these songs, but never recorded the longer versions. He was the lyricist for the theme song to "<a href="George%20of%20the%20Jungle">George of the Jungle</a>". Additionally, Allman worked with Stan Worth, co-writer of the "George of the Jungle" theme, to create music for a number of game shows by Stefan Hatos-Monty Hall Productions, including the 1970s versions of "<a href="Let%27s%20Make%20a%20Deal">Let's Make a Deal</a>", "<a href="Masquerade%20Party">Masquerade Party</a>" and "<a href="It%20Pays%20to%20be%20Ignorant">It Pays to be Ignorant</a>".
In 1960, Allman released "<a href="Folk%20music">Folk Songs</a> for the 21st Century", an album of novelty songs all revolving around science-fiction themes. The tongue-in-cheek material, which Allman wrote and arranged himself, included titles such as "Crawl Out Through The Fallout" and "Radioactive Mama." "Crawl Out Through The Fallout" is used in the video game "<a href="Fallout%204">Fallout 4</a>".
In addition, Allman co-wrote two <a href="comedy">comedy</a> <a href="Horror%20fiction">horror-themed</a> stage musicals with <a href="Bobby%20Pickett">Bobby Pickett</a>, composer of the hit novelty song, "<a href="Monster%20Mash">Monster Mash</a>." The musicals were "<a href="I%27m%20Sorry%20the%20Bridge%20Is%20Out%2C%20You%27ll%20Have%20to%20Spend%20the%20Night">I'm Sorry the Bridge Is Out, You'll Have to Spend the Night</a>" and its sequel, "<a href="Frankenstein%20Unbound%20%28Another%20Monster%20Musical%29">Frankenstein Unbound</a>", the former of which was made into the 1995 film, "<a href="Monster%20Mash%20%281995%20film%29">Monster Mash</a>".
Death.
On January 22, 2002, Allman died of heart failure at his home in Culver City, California, at age 77. His interment is in Culver City's <a href="Hillside%20Memorial%20Park%20Cemetery">Hillside Memorial Park Cemetery</a>.
